q: First hominin appeared in Africa. The hominin includes the Homo genus (humans) and Pan genus (chimpanzees).
First evidence of stone tools found in present day Kenya.
Homo erectus is the first hominin to migrate out of Africa. They have larger brains, dexterous fingers and long legs. They were the first to walk upright.
Oldest boats were found.
First use of fire, which leads to advancements in cooking meat lead to larger brain development.
A divergence happens within Homo erectus creating the Neanderthals and Denisovans.
Basic communication and language is suggested among Homo genus.
Begin the trade and transport of resources.

Homo Heidelbergensis evolves further. 
Does this evolutionary process take place?
Homo-sapiens emerge out of Africa and fill the globe quickly.
First evidence of wearing clothes.
Cultivating wild grains begin.

The earliest structures are found. 
Archaelogy believes that behavioral modernity happens granting Sapiens behavioral and cognitive traits, abstract thinking, symbolic behavior, and planning depth. 
Does the evolutionary step take place?
Homo floresiensis also known as Hobbits died out.
Homo sapiens arrive in Europe.
First evidence of abstract art.
Homo sapiens arrive in India.
First known musical instrument, a flute found in modern day Germany.
Extinction of Neanderthal. Human settlement of Australia.
Venus figurine found in Europe. Suggests a belief in Gods.
Evidence of domesticated dog skulls in Europe and Siberia.
Beginning of lighter skin in Europeans and East Asians.
People around the world use fibers to make baby carriers, clothes, bags, baskets, and nets.
Cave painting culture started in modern day France and spread throughout Europe.
Pottery is found in Japan.
First signs of warfare between tribes.
Extinction of late surviving archaic humans due to competition, interbreeding and climate change.
Human migration to North America.
Domestication of cats.

Start of the end of the Ice Age, megafauna (large animals) go extinct like the sabre-toothed cat and the mammoth abrupt period of global warming accelerates the glacial retreat. Rising sea levels seperate the Americas.

In northern Mesopotamia, now Iraq, cultivation of barley and wheat begins. 
Some hunters and gatherers experience dreams of beings, entrusting them these sacred grains, promising a future of food stability. 
Do these dreams influence their behavior?
The eight Neolithic founder crops, emmer and einkorn wheat, hulled barley, peas, lentils, bitter vetch, chick peas and flax were cultivated.
Beginnings of Agriculture in the Middle East.
Ice Age ends, allows for human migration to islands what is now Japan.
Wild sheep flocks are managed in Zagros mountain.
Alcohol fermentation starts in China.
Wooly mammoths go into serious decline.
Religious activity near Stonehenge, evidence shows it happened long before the monuments.
Ovens for pottery are used in the Near East.
Long distance trade in obsidian begins.
Humans inhabit Egypt.
Plant cultivation starts in North America.

Wild game start to decrease. Humans have started domestication of animals but rarely for food. 
Do humans domesticate animals for food?
Domesticated animals used for food increased during this period.
Domestication of goat and sheep.
The concentration of people, domesticated animals and livestock let to a surge of epidemics. Human population is plagued with diseases and decreases rapidly during the early days.
Jericho is the first major walled city with a population of around 2500. Populations sees a steady increase.
Possibly the last time Britain was connected to land.
Domestication of pigs.
Rice cultivation begins in the Yangtze River valley in China.
Copper is smelted in Anatolia, modern day Turkey.
Evidence of burial of the dead in Egypt.
Domestication of cattle.
Evidence of first irrigation system.
Cotton cultivation begins in India.
First sail boats were found.
Domestication of chicken begins in China.
Agriculture community develops in Faiyum (modern day Egypt) and in the Mesopotamia (modern day Syria).
Gold and silver are used in Egypt for jewellery.
Hiearchal cities emerge in Europe.
Cuneiform scripts are developed by Sumerians in Mesopotamia to communicate trade between cities.

People in Sumeria built their first temples. 
Do the temples get built?
Invention of the plow.
Rise of cities in Tigris and Euphrates river.
Farming settlements established in the Indus Valley. Docks are built for trade.
Use of wool for textiles.
Evidence of Bronze working. Beginning of Bronze Age.
Last wooly mamoth die out in Siberia.
Invention of the wheel.
Writing is invented in Sumer at Uruk with cunieform letters.
Saharan desert spread throughout Africa because of climate change.
Farming spreads across Europe.
First evidence of religion in Sumerian cunieform.
First evidence of currency in the form of Bronze coins.
Stonehenge begins construction.
Evidence of sea-going ships, by Austronesians, modern-day Southern China, Taiwan.
Potatoes are grown in the Andes.
The domestication of the alpaca also begins in the Andes.
First bronze age settlement in Jerusaleum.
Period of Great Flood when Euphrates rose.
The first secular rulers appear instead of priests.
The Egyptian wrting develops the alphabet using hieroglyphs to represent syllables.
Cultivation of corn begins in Mesopotamia.

First war is recorded in History between Elam and Sumer. The King of Kish commands the forces of the Sumer against the Elamites over what is now modern-day Iraq. 
Does this war proceed according to History?
The Sumerians defeat the Elamites.
King Djoser of Egypt builds the first pyramid.
King Sneferu of Egypt builds the first true pyramid.
Mayan culture appears in the Yacan Peninsula.
Pharaoh Khufu constructs the Great Pyramid of Giza.
Papyrus is used for writing for the first time. The first material for paper.
The Great Sphinx of Giza is built.
The Egyptians develop filigree technique that allows the manufacturing of gold products.
Evidence of metal working found in Ireland.
First use of war chariots in Mesopotamia.
Widespread use and production of soap.

The reign of Sargon of Akkad begins in Mesopotamia. He intends to expand his land through conquest. 
Does he become the first known Empire?

Sargon fought and won 34 battles across Mesopotamia and expanded the Akkadian empire from present-day Iran to Syria in the west, the Persian Gulf in the south, and into present-day Turkey in the north.
Beer is brewed in Egypt.
First written code of laws king Ur-Nammu of Mesopotamia.
Beginning of the 4.2 kiloyear event. A 100-year period of ultra-dry conditions worldwide.

The Indus Valley civilization disappears. However civilizations spawn in North America, Europe and China. 
In Europe, the Minoans form on the Island of Crete. However a volcano erupts and the Mycenean Greeks arise. This eruption could have birthed the Atlantis myth. 
The Akkadian Empire evolves into the Babylonian Empire.
The poem of Gilgamesh of the Babylonian Empire in Mesopotamia first describes the apocalypse. Music also becomes widespread.
Horses become domesticated in Mesopotamia.
Trade flourishes and expands. Mesopotamia and Palestine become important trade hub.
The Egypt Book of the End is written in papyrus.
First professional army of formed in Egypt under king Amenemhat I.
The Kahun Gynecological Papyrus writes about women's health and contraception.
Reign of Hammurabi, king of Babylon.
The Code of Hammurabi is written, one of the earlies complete code of laws in the world.
Hammurabi rules the first Babylonian Empire over the whole of Mesopotamia.
The Shang Dynasty in China begins. Writing develops under their rule.
Mycenaean Greece civilization thrives.
The Phoenician alphabet is developed which becomes the foundation for the Greeks.
Palestine is absorbed by the Egyptian Empire.
The Egyptian Empire extends to the Euphrates and is at it's greatest extent.
Indian scholars commit the Vedas to written form, the basic tenets of Hinduism are established. The origin of the Vedas are unknown.
The sundial is invented in Mesopotamia, using the sun is used to measure time.
The Bronze Age reaches Scotland.
Evidence of oldest known song.
The Egyptian Empire declines under the rule of Akhenaten.
Trade agreements are restored under the reign of King Horemheb and the Egyptian Empire revives.
The Trojan War is fought between Greeks and the city of Troy. First mentioned in Homer's Iliad, the story defines Greek culture.

Beginning of the Dark Ages, a period where historical records go blank. The Minocean Greeks and the Egyptian Kingdom disappear. The Indo-Iranians migrate to India. During this period however, several world legends are born including the Jewish Torah, the Hindu Mahabharata and the Hebrew Bible.
Ancient Greek civilization begins in Greece and the Mediterranean.
Evidence of the worship of Yahweh, the monotheistic god and 10 commandments which was brought by the returning Jews to Jerusalem.
The first Temple of Judaism is built in Jerusalem.
Homer of Greece writes his Illiad and Odyssey.
The oracle of Zeus is established in Dodona.
Greek alphabetic script is developed.
The Olmec civilization begins in central America.
First athletic games in honor of Zeus, held at Olympia with one event, the foot race.
An Ancient Greek lawyer named Draco writes down the Draconian laws in Athens. Some are punishable by death.
The legendary founding date for the city of Rome. Beginning of Classic Antiquity.
The legendary founding date for the city of Rome. Beginning of Classic Antiquity.
The Assyrian Empire conquers Israel. Part of the Jewish population travels to Jeruselam and Judea.
The Greek builds the first medical school.
The Assyrian Empire evades Egypt. It turns into the first Persian Empire or the Achaemenid Empire under Cyrus the Great.
The crossbow is invented in China.
Birth of Lao Tzu, founder of Daoism.
Thales of Mietus discovers static electricity He is regarded as one of the first Western philosophers and mathematicians.
The Neo-Babylonian Empire conquers Jerusalem and destroys the First Temple prompting the Jewish people to move to Babylon, the capital.
The archon Solon of Ancient Greek lays the foundation for democracy, replacing Draconian laws in Athens.
Birth of Pythagoras, a Greek mathematician who made major advances in science, math and philosophy. He is also the first to propose Earth is a sphere and that the soul is immortal.
Birth of Siddhartha Gautama, a prince from Nepal and later founder of Buddhism.
Kong Fuzi is born, founder of Confucianism.
The Persian Empire by Cyrus the Great reigns over the Mesopotamia, Egypt and Central Asia.
They adopted Zoroastrianism which was based on the Iranian prophet Zoroaster who believed in a single unifying God, at a time of dominant polytheism.
The Persian Empire conquers Ionian Greece. The Persians believed in Zurvanism, a sect derived from Zoroastrianism and believed humans were given free-will.
The Persian Empire under Darius the Great conquers Egypt, Thrace (modern day Turkey) and Macedonia. It is its largest extent.

Democracy introduced into Athens by Cleisthenes. He establishes a constitution and is often called the “Father of Athenian Democracy”. Romans rise up against King Tarquinius and establish the Roman republic.
The Persian Empire conquers Babylon but allows freedom of religion. Jewish people return to Jerusalem and thrive.
Nazca people of Peru experimented with balloon fight.
Around this time was the life of Sun-Tzu, a military strategist and writer of the Art of War.
Greek playwright Sophocles is born, who suggests a moderation in dreeking beer. The Romans build a temple dedicated to Saturn.
The battle of Marathon, the Greek forces lead by Alexander the Great defeat the Persians Empire.
Herodotus is born. A Greek historian, he used systematic investigation to write history books and is the founder of modern history.

Socrates is born. He introduces morality and ethics and theorizes an ethics system based on human reason. He rejected the scientific teachings at the time as was accused of being an "atheist" and eventually trialed. He believed in technocracy and was a critic of democracy. 
Socrates was considered a controversial yet influencial philosopher, should his teachings be censored?
Democritus is born. He is the first to theorize the atom theory to explain the physical world. He is largely ignored.
Pericles, a democratic populist leader becomes ruler of Athens. He sparks an age of cultural innovation.
First klepsydra is made, a water time keeping device used in Athens.
The Pantheon, the Roman temple begins construction.
Plato is born. He introduces Plato school of thought.
Socrates is condemned to death for "corrupting the youth". Socrates states: "All of philosophy is training for death."
Plato writes about the Lost City of Atlantis.
Alexander the Great becomes the ruler of Macedonia, an allied kingdom to Athens.
Aristotle's the Politics is written which theorizes the "mind" over "body" and the supremacy of the civilized man.
Alexander the Great claims Persia and takes hold of Palestine. He is conquers Egypt and is crowned a Pharaoh.
Alexander the Great does not conquer any neighboring land. He rules over Macedonia and a general to the Greek forces. The lineage of Pharaohs rule Egypt.
Alexander the Great dies at age 32, the Macedonian empire spans across Pelly, Babylon, Egypt and even the Indus Valley.
Alexander the Great continues to rule over Macedonia and now Sparta, another city-state.
Ptolemy I becomes one of the successors of the Greek Empire. He weakens the Empire overtime and is eventually succeeded by Cleopatra a greek queen who rules only over Egypt.
Egypt is ruled by it's native kingdoms.
Jerusalem becomes absorbed into the Greek Empire. Hellenic culture and Jewish culture develop friction.
Chandragupta Maurya fends off the Seleucid Empire (remnants of Alexander the Great's Empire). He then forms the Mauryan Empire in India.
The Mauryan kingdom is founded in India.
Completion of Euclid's Elements. Euclid, a Greek mathematician is considered the father of geometry.
King Ptolemy II of Philadelphus of Egypt expands sea trade.
Reign of Ashoka the Great of the Mauryan Empire who establishes Buddhism across India.
Ashoka sends a missionary lead by his son to spread Buddhism to Sri Lanka.
The Parthian Empire is found in Greek Hellinistic kingdom, the second native dynasty of Persia.

In Greek Hellinistic kingdom, the second native dynasty of Persia rises. 
Does this kingdom become the Parthian Empire?
The Torah is translated into Greek in Alexandria, Egypt.
The Qin dynasty unites China and begins construction on the Great Wall of China. He makes Daoism and legalism, state tenets.
The Qin dynasty unites China and builds the Great Wall of China.
Emperor Qin Shi Huang builds the terracotta army as a funeral art burried alongside him.
The Han dynasty establish Confucianism as the state religion. They also build ships with sails having learnt from Malaysian visitors.
Paper is invented in China under Liu Bang the first Han ruler.
China comes into contact with the Greco-Barbarian , descendants of Alexander the Great.
Iron manufacturing in the Celtics, North of Europe experiences a significant boom in weapons and tool manufacturing. In North America, the Mayan city of El Mirador thrives.
The Aryans, meaning "free people" from various ethnics from the Iran Plateau migrate to Eurasia and to India.
The Third Macedonian War between the Roman Republic and Macedon, the successor state of Alexander the Great's Empire.
The Romans defeat Carthage, a Phoenician colony. Rome extends to modern-day Tunisia and Libya.
The Roman Republic conquer Greece.

The Roman Republic and Greek Republic are the largest Western civiizations in Europe. The Phoenician Carthage civilization rules Libya and Tunisia. 
Do the Roman Republic conquer them?

The Romans defeat Carthage and then conquer Greece. The Ancient Greeks are absorbed into the Roman Republic. The Parthians see the new Roman Empire as an immediate threat and begins conquering more land.
Zhang Qian, an envoy of Emperor Wu, opens the Silk Road, a major trading route between China and central Asia.
The Silk Road connects East and West worlds together for the first time. China conquests Vietnam.
The Parthians conquer Mesopotamia. The Silk Road to China is now controlled by the Parthians.
Roman armies enter Gaul for the first time what is now modern day France, Belgium and Luxembourg and Switzerland
The Celtics continue to occupy modern day . Germanic tribes move south from Scandinavia
Beginning of the Chinese occupation of Nanyue, modern day Vietnam
Bantu speaking tribes produce carbon steel in Africa.
The Han dynasty in China invades Mongolia.
Native civilizations of Vietnam and Mongolia thrive.
The Roman Republican standardizes Old Latin into Classical Latin.
The Roman Empire conquers Jerusalem.
Jerusalem remains a Jewish settlement.

Cleopatra IV is restored to the Ptolemy throne as ruler of Egypt. 15 years later She loses in battle to Octavian Caesar, Julius' adopted nephew and Egypt becomes part of the Roman Empire. Julius Caesar also establishes himself as dictator.

Apart from the Roman and Greek civilizations. Much of Europe is still sparsely populated. There still remains various groups of agrarian communities such as the Celtics and Germanic tribes in the North.
The Caesar Civil War in Rome, with Julius Caesar against the Roman Senate. Caesar emerges victorious.
The Roman Republic prevails. Julius Caesar attempts to overthrow democracy and establish an dictatorship but is advised by his senators not to.

Roman senators become increasingly worried about Julius Caesar's tyrannical nature and plan to assassinate him. 
Does this event take place?

Julius Caesar is murdered by Marcus Brutus and other senators. Octavian Caesar takes over and changes his name to Augustus Caesar and founds the Roman Principate, a period with only one Roman Emperor.
Julius Caesar's powers gradually weaken.
The Roman Republic conquest Egypt. Cleopatra ends her reign as the last ruler of the Ptolemic kingdom.
The Roman Republic turns into an Empire
The African Kingdom of Kush attacks the Romans lead by Amanirenas, the queen of the Kushites.
The African Kingdom of Kush attacks the Romans lead by Amanirenas, the queen of the Kushites.
Julius Caesar dies of old age and a democratic elected senator takes over
The end
Evolution have not been kind. Homo sapiens were quickly wiped out due to competition with the Neanderthals who have mastered stone tools
Evolution didn't take place. Not to worry, homo sapiens are still thriving.
Just dreams, the hunters and gatherers continued on their days. Use of barley and wheat does not transcend to bread. Bread is never invented.
The Ice Age starts to warm but we continue our hunter and gatherer ways.
Wild sheep flocks are managed in Zagros mountain.
Wooly mammoths go into serious decline.
Religious activity near Stonehenge, evidence shows it happened long before the monuments.
Long distance trade in obsidian begins.
Humans inhabit Egypt.
Plant cultivation starts in North America.
As humans continue to hunt, wild game decreases, humans resort to eating a more varied plant based diet.

To increase diets from lack of wild game, cultivation of barley and wheat begins. Some hunters and gatherers experience dreams of god beings, entrusting them these sacred grains, promising a future of food stability. 
Do these dreams influence their behavior?
The eight Neolithic founder crops, emmer and einkorn wheat, hulled barley, peas, lentils, bitter vetch, chick peas and flax were cultivated
Agriculture is founded in the Middle East. The Ice Age ends. Humans migrate to Japan.
Homo floresiensis also known as Hobbits died out.
Homo sapiens arrive in Europe.
Homo sapiens arrive in India.
Extinction of Neanderthals. Human settlement of Australia.
light skin in Europeans and East Asians
First signs of warfare between tribes.
Extinction. Homo sapiens were severely disadvantaged compared to the other archaic humans who had already developed stone weapons.
The imagination of spiritual entities is not shared by the collective. Some people are just too busy to think about such things.
Invention of the plow.
The Sumerians and the Elamites negotiate their differences.
Sargon rules Mesopotamia and does not conquer.
